An eKanban system sending real-time demand signals and providing 
continuous status updates that are visible throughout the plant, can greatly 
reduce the need for physical interactions and ultimately, variability. 
Building Trust in the System
eKanbans can serve to create one source of truth throughout the system.  As 
eKanban signaling is utilized, the amount of variability throughout the process is 
reduced and each step begins to trust the previous step.  This reduces the need 
to add extra protection everywhere in the supply chain.  eKanban

Document 260: 12
The inputs to MRP (the master schedule, BOM, lead times, purchasing, and 
inventory) frequently change. These frequent changes generate what is called 
system nervousness and can create havoc in purchasing and production 
departments if implemented. OM personnel reduce such nervousness by 
evaluating the need and impact of changes prior to disseminating requests to 
other departments by using two tools: Time fences & Pegging . 
Time fences allow a segment of the master schedule to be designated as “not 
to be rescheduled.”
Pegging means tracing upward in the BOM from the component to the parent 
item. By pegging upward, the production planner can determine the cause for 
the requirement and make a judgment about the necessity for a change in the 
schedule.

Customer Order-Driven, Pull-Based Kanban 
Systems
Pull-based systems represent the other end of the spectrum. Pull systems 
are based on the Toyota Production System (TPS) and its western 
interpretation, “Lean Manufacturing”. The Pull method from TPS is often 
referred to as a Kanban system – a method for planning, execution and 
inventory replenishment that enables flow through greater control.

adjusted and reported back up the chain. This slow and often arduous 
feedback loop doesn’t offer much flexibility to quickly respond to the inevitable 
variation in customer demand and execution to the plan. Rather, it often leads 
to a negative spiral of adding inventory, clogging up production and leading to 
diminished capacity and loss of control.  This is the very opposite of what we 
are trying to achieve with our systems.

Document 203: 11CONWIP Vs Pure Push System:
CONWIP exhibits the following advantages over a pure 
push system:
•The WIP level is directly observable, while the release rate in a 
push system must be set with respect to (unobservable) capacity.
•It requires less WIP on average to attain the same throughput.
•It facilitates working ahead of a schedule when favorable 
circumstances permit it.

Document 209: 17Summary
•Push systems schedule the release of work on the basis of 
demand information, while pull systems authorize the release 
of work on the basis of inventory status within the system.
•The “magic” of pull systems is that they establish a WIP cap, which prevents producing unnecessary WIP that does not 
signiﬁcantly improve throughput.
•The simplest mechanism for establishing a WIP cap is 
CONWIP (constant work in process), in which the WIP level 
in a line is held constant by synchronizing releases to departures.
Copyright © 2008 by Wallace J. Hopp and Mark C. Spearman

Push v. Pull Planning and Execution Systems     
in Manufacturing
The contrast between Push and Pull-based systems starts at the planning 
phase. In traditional Push-based MRP/ERP environments, a plan is developed 
and pushed through the system. The assumption for planning in a Push 
environment is that everything remains constant; the company has the 
capacity on hand, along with the inventory and decision support staff to 
execute the plan. And while seemingly proactive, the plan often becomes 
obsolete before it is executed as it cannot easily accommodate changes in 
market conditions or adjust to variations inherent in manufacturing 
environments.  manufacturing so ftware

Document 145: Introduction
This is the first in a series of papers exploring the nature of Pull-based 
manufacturing systems and specifically, Kanban systems. The focus of this 
paper is at the system, or workflow level, while subsequent publications will 
review Pull/Kanban systems from a management, customer and competitive 
standpoint. After reading this paper, you will have a good understanding of 
both Pull and Push-based manufacturing systems and your choices for 
systems within a Pull environment. After reading the collection of papers, you 
should have a 360-degree perspective of the impact of a Pull/Kanban system 
in an organization.

Overlapping is a method that processes part of the lot on the work center 
performing the second operation, while the rest of the lot is still in the work 
center in the first operation. Overlapping reduces lead time in a way similar to 
parallel processing.
Operations Splitting: Throughput time decreases as only part of the lot is 
processed on one machine. 
Lot Splitting /Order Splitting: A lot (or order) is split, and a part of it is run 
ahead of schedule in a period where there is available capacity.

Kanban system is one such tool that represents a visual and functional step in 
the transition from Push to Pull processing.  While there are Kanban systems 
for a variety of purposes (software development, project management, even 
personal productivity Kanbans), in the manufacturing world, we make the 
distinction between manual and electronic – or eKanban software systems.

evaluations.model_response:
In time series decomposition, the difference between additive and multiplicative seasonal variation lies in how the seasonal component is combined with the trend and the original data. 

In additive seasonal variation, the seasonal factor is added to the trend to create the forecast, meaning the seasonal variation remains relatively constant throughout the series:
Forecast including trend and seasonal = Trend + Seasonal

In multiplicative seasonal variation, the seasonal factor is multiplied by the trend to create the forecast, meaning the seasonal variation changes in relation to the magnitude of the data:
Forecast including trend and seasonal = Trend × Seasonal factor

These variations are used depending on the time series data's behavior and the specific requirements of the forecasting problem.

Based on the provided context, a firm can use strategies such as contingency planning, insurance, working with multiple suppliers, and maintaining safety stock to reduce risk in the face of high levels of supply uncertainty. These strategies are part of the risk mitigation strategies mentioned in the document.

Takt Time in operations management is the rate of demand from the customer, calculated by dividing the total available production time by the number of units required to meet customer demand. It sets the pace of production to match the pace of customer need, and is a key metric in managing flow in a production system.

An ERP system can streamline hotel and resort operations in the following ways:

1. Room booking system: This feature allows for efficient management of room reservations and availability.
2. Guest management: ERP systems can maintain comprehensive guest information, including preferences and history, to enhance customer service.
3. Front-desk efficiency: By integrating various functions such as room keys, guest check-in/check-out, and billing, ERP systems can improve front-desk efficiency.
4. Inventory management: Effective tracking and management of hotel supplies and resources can be achieved through ERP systems.
5. Housekeeping, laundry, and maintenance: ERP systems can help schedule and track housekeeping tasks, manage laundry operations, and maintain equipment, contributing to overall maintenance management.

Some benefits of using eKanban systems include:

1. Real-time tracking of supermarket and kanban status.
2. Instantaneous adjustments based on demand.
3. Fast and consistent communication across the supplier network.

Sure, I'd be happy to explain the key differences between a Pull and Push-based system in the context of inventory management.

In a Push system, work is released based on a pre-determined schedule or forecast, which is driven by demand. This means that production is planned and materials are ordered based on a forecast of what is expected to be needed, regardless of actual demand. This approach can lead to excess inventory and inefficiencies if the forecast is inaccurate.

On the other hand, in a Pull system, work is released based on actual demand and the current inventory status. This means that production is only triggered when there is a demand for a product and there is insufficient inventory to meet that demand. Pull systems are driven by the consumption of inventory and are designed to be more responsive to changes in demand.

The key differences between these two systems are:

* In a Push system, work is scheduled and released based on a forecast, whereas in a Pull system, work is authorized based on actual demand and inventory status.
* Push systems are inherently due-date driven and control the release rate, while Pull systems are inherently rate driven and control the WIP (work-in-progress) level.
* Push systems are front-loaded in planning and rigid in execution, while Pull systems focus on the execution of the customer order and are designed to be agile enough to respond quickly to changes in demand.

Overall, Pull systems are generally considered to be more efficient and effective in managing inventory and responding to changes in demand, but they may require more effort to implement and manage than Push systems.

Implementing CONWIP over a pure push system in a typical organization that transforms inputs into outputs can offer several benefits. CONWIP, a pull system, directly observes the Work-in-Progress (WIP) level, while a pure push system sets the release rate with respect to unobservable capacity. CONWIP requires less WIP on average for the same throughput and allows working ahead of schedule when possible.

Additionally, CONWIP helps reduce costs by preventing WIP explosions, reducing average WIP, and minimizing engineering changes. It improves quality by creating pressure for higher quality, enhancing defect detection, and fostering better communication. CONWIP also improves customer service with reduced cycle time variability, pressure to reduce process variability sources, and encouragement of shorter lead times and better on-time performance.

Furthermore, CONWIP maintains flexibility for organizations by avoiding early job release, reducing direct congestion, decreasing reliance on forecasts, and promoting floating capacity. Implementing CONWIP, with its inherent WIP cap, prevents producing unnecessary WIP that does not significantly boost throughput.

Sure, in manufacturing environments that are subject to frequent changes in market conditions, the primary distinctions between Push and Pull-based systems are as follows:

1. Planning Phase: In Push-based systems, a plan is developed and pushed through the system, assuming that everything remains constant. In contrast, Pull-based systems are driven from a high-level perspective that focuses on capacity and material planning based on actual customer demand.

2. Rigidity: Push-based systems are front-loaded in planning and rigid in execution, making it difficult to accommodate changes in market conditions or manufacturing variations. On the other hand, Pull-based systems focus on the execution of the customer order and are designed to be agile enough to respond quickly to changes in demand.

3. Decision Making: In Push-based systems, decisions are made based on forecasts, while in Pull-based systems, decisions are made based on actual customer demand.

4. Flexibility: Pull-based systems are more flexible and adaptable to changes in market conditions compared to Push-based systems.

In summary, Push-based systems are more rigid and plan-driven, while Pull-based systems are more agile and responsive to actual customer demand.

Little's Law is a mathematical relationship in the context of production process mapping, which describes the connection between inventory, throughput, and flow time. It is expressed as Inventory = Throughput rate x Flow time. Inventory refers to the amount of inventory of all types in the process, throughput rate is the average rate at which items move from being inputs to outputs, and flow time is the average time it takes for an item to move through the process. This law helps in understanding and optimizing the production process by analyzing these three key elements.

In operations and supply chain management, forecasting affects various management decisions across different functions. 

There are four primary types of forecasts used in this field:

1. Qualitative forecasts: These rely on expert judgment or opinions and are often used when historical data is unavailable or difficult to interpret. Examples include market research, executive opinion, and the Delphi method.

2. Time series analysis: This type of forecasting is based on the idea that past demand data can be used to predict future demand. Time series analysis techniques include simple moving average, weighted moving average, exponential smoothing, and linear regression.

3. Causal relationships: Forecasting based on causal relationships examines the impact of independent variables on the dependent variable (demand) to create a more accurate forecast.

4. Simulation: Simulation forecasting uses mathematical models to represent complex systems and their relationships, enabling the examination of various scenarios and their effects on demand.

These forecasting methods can be employed in different ways by various functions:

- Finance and accounting use forecasts as the basis for budgeting and cost control.
- Marketing utilizes forecasts for new product planning and personnel compensation.
- Production depends on forecasts to select suppliers, determine capacity requirements, and drive decisions about purchasing, staffing, and inventory.

In addition to these types, forecasts can be categorized as strategic or tactical based on their time horizon. Strategic forecasts, which are longer-term, are used for forecasting demand for a group of products, while tactical forecasts cover only a short period of time. Forecast quality is measured based on its error. Qualitative techniques, such as market research and executive opinion, typically depend more on judgment or expert opinions.

Goldratt's Rule 6 of Production Scheduling states that 'Bottlenecks govern both throughput and inventory in the system.' This rule highlights the significant impact of bottlenecks on a system's productivity and inventory levels. 

On the other hand, Goldratt's Rule 3 states that 'Utilization and activation of a resource are not the same.' Utilization refers to the amount of time a resource is in use, while activation refers to the act of putting a resource into use. According to this rule, keeping a non-bottleneck resource highly utilized is not as important as ensuring that bottleneck resources are used effectively.

These two rules differ in their focus. Rule 6 emphasizes the system-wide impact of bottlenecks, while Rule 3 distinguishes between the utilization and activation of resources, highlighting the importance of effectively managing bottleneck resources.

Sure, based on the provided context, here are some key distinctions:

1. Services vs. Goods: Services are intangible, require interaction with the customer, are heterogeneous, perishable and time-dependent, and are defined and evaluated as a package of features. Goods, on the other hand, are tangible and can be owned, have consistent characteristics, and are evaluated based on their performance, features, reliability/durability, serviceability, aesthetics, perceived quality, and safety.

2. Order Winners vs. Order Qualifiers: Order winners are the criteria used by customers to differentiate the products and services of one firm from those of other firms. These are the features that customers use to determine which product to ultimately purchase. Order qualifiers, on the other hand, are those dimensions that are necessary for a firm's products to be considered for purchase by customers. These are features customers will not forego.

3. Dimensions of Product Quality: The dimensions of product quality include performance (the basic operating characteristics of a product), features (the "extra" items added to the basic feature), reliability/durability (the consistency of performance over time, probability of failing, and useful life), serviceability (the ease of repair, the speed of repair), aesthetics (the sensory characteristics such as sound, feel, look, and so on), perceived quality (past performance and reputation), and safety (assurance that the customer will not suffer injury or harm from the product).
